elements.content: Silver imidazolecarbaldehyde oxime complexes [Ag­(1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime)2]­[NO3] (1), [Ag­(1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime)2]­[ClO3] (2), [Ag­(1H-5-methylimidazole-4-carbaldehyde oxime)]2­[NO3]2 (3), [Ag­(1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime)] n ­[NO3] n (4), [Ag­(1H-4-methylimidazole-5-carbaldehyde oxime)] n ­[ClO3] n (5), and [Ag­(N-hydroxy-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboximidamide)2]2­[CF3SO3]2 (6) were structurally and computationally analyzed. Weak intramolecular interactions were found to play the main role in determining the most favorable structure of the free ligands, therefore controlling the final coordination mode, and the nuclearity of the complexes. Further information on the nature of the intra- and intermolecular interactions were provided utilizing computational density functional theory calculations and topological charge density analysis according to the Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules. The efficient control of the structure of the complexes also results in a better control of the material properties.

elements.content: Controlling the final structure of the product formed is of utmost importance in chemical synthesis because the structure most often determines the properties of the material. However, being able to control the structure of the material is also a very challenging task, especially when dealing with transition metal complexes with multidentate ligands that can organize in many different ways in the coordination sphere. Using ligands with variable donor atoms is very beneficial since their metal complexes often lead to materials with interesting and desirable electronic and optical properties, and can be exploited in diverse applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Controlling the final structure of the product formed is of utmost importance in chemical synthesis because the structure most often determines the properties of the material. However, being able to control the structure of the material is also a very challenging task, especially when dealing with transition metal complexes with multidentate ligands that can organize in many different ways in the coordination sphere. Using ligands with variable donor atoms is very beneficial since their metal complexes often lead to materials with interesting and desirable electronic and optical properties, and can be exploited in diverse applications.

elements.content: Oximes are a class of important functional ligands, which have been utilized, for example, in medicine, magnetism, catalysis, and crystal engineering. Oximes are versatile ligands, which can be easily tailored to yield materials with distinct characteristics. The synthesis, coordination, and reactivity of oximes have been reviewed, for instance, in the extensive paper by Milios et al., and also by Kukushkin and Pombeiro. Generally, the neutral oxime group >CNOH exhibits one active nitrogen for binding with metal ions, and therefore, it acts as a monodentate ligand with terminal coordination. However, using different substituents in the oxime carbon creates a large number of possibilities for affecting the coordination mode depending on whether the substituents have additional coordination sites, such as with pyridine or phenol, or do not have additional coordination sites, as with the cyclohexane substituent. The location of the coordinative donor atoms in the substituent also has a major effect on the structure of the material, which can be seen, for example, in comparing coordination of 2-pyridyl oxime, which normally creates a chelating mononuclear complex, to that of 3-pyridyl oxime or 4-pyridyl oxime, which have been found to preferably lead to polymeric chain-like structures via terminal coordination. The stereochemistry of the oxime group itself (either E or Z isomer) can affect the structure of the coordination complex. Furthermore, by deprotonating the oxime OH group, it is possible to form complexes with a large variety of nuclearity using the negative oxygens for additional coordination. Further manipulating the ligands by introducing two (or more) oxime groups will lead to increasing the possibilities for coordination, and, for example, multinuclear mixed metal complexes can be designed. Finally, exploiting relatively strong hydrogen bonding interactions involving the oxime OH group has been found to affect the self-assembly of the complexes in the solid state, therefore influencing their crystal packing a great deal.

elements.content: Even though oximes have been a subject of active research for a long time, no systematic investigation on the control of the coordination modes has been reported. Moreover, imidazole oximes have been mostly neglected over the years, despite their important medical applications. For example, imidazole oximes have been suggested to mimic the function of the histidine amino acid, their copper complexes have been investigated for the DNA binding activities, and ruthenium imidazole oximes have been suggested to function as CO-releasing agents for therapeutic use. Imidazole oximes have also been applied in the extraction of metal ions from solution.

elements.content: Imidazole oximes have two potential donor nitrogens with completely different electronic environments, the aromatic imidazole nitrogen and the oxime nitrogen. Furthermore, certain imidazoles have two tautomeric forms with a different relative orientation of the protonated nitrogen. Even this seemingly small change in the ligand structure can change the geometry of coordination sphere and have a major effect on the binding to metal ions.

elements.content: In this study, we aimed to find an explanation of the factors affecting the versatile coordination modes and the rich chemistry of the imidazole oximes by conducting a systematic study on their coordination properties in metal complexes. We focused on a variety of neutral imidazolecarbaldehyde oxime ligands and their binding with silver salts. In principle, neutral imidazole oximes can exhibit several different coordination modes to metal ions utilizing either only one of the donor atoms, which would result in terminal coordination, or both yielding chelated or bridged complexes. The different options for coordination are summarized in .

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentations

All manipulations were performed at room temperature and under aerobic conditions. AgNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich, 99+%), AgClO3 (Aldrich, 99.9+%), AgCF3SO3(Alfa Aesar, 98+%) were commercially available and used as received. 1-Methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime, 1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime, N-hydroxy-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboximiamide, and 1H-4(5)-methylimidazole-5(4)-carbaldehyde oxime were prepared as described in the literature. The elemental analysis (EA) was determined by varioMICRO V1.7, and Bruker Avance 400 MHz was used for the 1H NMR. The X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker AXS Smart Apex II diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å).

elements.content: The crystals of complexes 1–6 were immersed in cryo-oil, mounted in a Nylon loop, and measured at the temperature of 120 K. The X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX II Duo diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The APEX2 program package was used for cell refinements and data reductions. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-2013 programs with WinGX graphical user interface. A semiempirical absorption correction (SADABS) was applied to all data. Structural refinements were carried out using SHELXL-2013.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Determination

The crystals of complexes 1-6 were immersed in cryo-oil, mounted in a Nylon loop, and measured at the temperature of 120 K. The X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX II Duo diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The APEX2 program package was used for cell refinements and data reductions. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-2013 programs with WinGX graphical user interface. A semiempirical absorption correction (SADABS) was applied to all data. Structural refinements were carried out using SHELXL-2013.

Distance restraints were applied to these C–H and O–H bonds in 1, 2, and 5, oxime C–H and imidazole N–H bonds in 4, N–H and O–H bonds in 6.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Complexes 1-6 

A new series of silver-imidazole carbaldehyde oxime complexes were synthesized. Silver salts with various anions were tested in the reactions, but those which yielded single crystals in ambient temperature and in aerobic condition were selected.

elements.content: All models were calculated with the Gaussian 09 program package at the DFT level of theory. The hybrid density functional PBE0 was utilized together with the basis set consisting of the def2-TZVPPD effective core potential basis set with triple-ζ-valence basis set with two sets of polarization and diffuse basis functions for Ag atoms and the standard all-electron basis set 6-31G­(d,p) for all other atoms. To study the electronic and interaction properties of the complexes, we performed topological charge density analysis with the QTAIM method, which allowed us to access the nature of the bonding via calculating different properties of the electron density at the bond critical points. The analysis was done with the AIMAll program using the wave functions obtained from the DFT calculations. The selected properties are ρ = local electron density at the BCP; Laplacian (∇2ρ) = second derivative of ρ; |V|/G = ratio of potential energy density (V) and kinetic energy density (G); E INT = interaction energy between two interacting atoms =1/2 × V(BCP) as defined by Espinosa et al.; δ­(A, B) = delocalization index between two (bonding) atoms; q(A) = total atomic charge of atom A according to AIM analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

All models were calculated with the Gaussian 09 program package at the DFT level of theory. The hybrid density functional PBE0 was utilized together with the basis set consisting of the def2-TZVPPD effective core potential basis set with triple-ζ-valence basis set with two sets of polarization and diffuse basis functions for Ag atoms and the standard all-electron basis set 6-31G(d,p) for all other atoms. To study the electronic and interaction properties of the complexes, we performed topological charge density analysis with the QTAIM method, which allowed us to access the nature of the bonding via calculating different properties of the electron density at the bond critical points. The analysis was done with the AIMAll program using the wave functions obtained from the DFT calculations. The selected properties are ρ = local electron density at the BCP; Laplacian (∇2ρ) = second derivative of ρ; |V|/G = ratio of potential energy density (V) and kinetic energy density (G); E INT = interaction energy between two interacting atoms =1/2 × V(BCP) as defined by Espinosa et al.; δ(A, B) = delocalization index between two (bonding) atoms; q(A) = total atomic charge of atom A according to AIM analysis.

elements.content: Full optimizations were performed on the free ligands before the AIM analysis. The models for the solid state structures were directly cut from the corresponding experimental crystal structures and analyzed without geometry optimization. The properties of the electron density for the complexes 1–6 are presented in Table S3 in the Supporting Information.

The models for the solid state structures were directly cut from the corresponding experimental crystal structures and analyzed without geometry optimization. The properties of the electron density for the complexes 1-6 are presented in Table S3 in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Four different imidazolecarbaldehyde oximes, 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime (L1), 1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime (L2), N-hydroxy-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboximidamide (L3), and 1H-4­(5)-methylimidazole-5­(4)-carbaldehyde oxime L4 (mixture of tautomers 1H-5-methylimidazole-4-carbaldehyde oxime L4A and 1H-4-methylimidazole-5-carbaldehyde oxime L4B), were reacted with silver salts AgNO3, AgClO3, and AgCF3SO3. The neutral imidazolecarbaldehyde oxime ligands have two possible coordination sites, the N-bonding site at the aromatic imidazole ring, the “head”, and the N- bonding site in the oxime functional group, the “tail”. In this work, we studied four different imidazolecarbaldehyde oxime ligands L1, L2, L3, and L4, presented in . The ligands were selected in order to create versatile possibilities for the two donor atoms to react and to form different kinds of coordination. On the other hand, using neutral oximes limited the coordination sites to two, since the oxime OH group could not directly coordinate. At the first stage, the electronic and geometric properties of the free ligands were studied in order to reveal their ability to coordinate with metal centers. The geometry of the ligands was fully optimized at the DFT level of theory and analyzed according to the QTAIM method. shows the Laplacian of the electron density for ligands L1–L4A (the corresponding Laplacian in ligand L4B is shown in the Supporting Information, Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Properties of the Free Imidazolecarbaldehyde Oxime Ligands

The neutral imidazolecarbaldehyde oxime ligands have two possible coordination sites, the N-bonding site at the aromatic imidazole ring, the "head", and the N- bonding site in the oxime functional group, the "tail". In this work, we studied four different imidazolecarbaldehyde oxime ligands L1, L2, L3, and L4, presented in . The ligands were selected in order to create versatile possibilities for the two donor atoms to react and to form different kinds of coordination. On the other hand, using neutral oximes limited the coordination sites to two, since the oxime OH group could not directly coordinate. At the first stage, the electronic and geometric properties of the free ligands were studied in order to reveal their ability to coordinate with metal centers. The geometry of the ligands was fully optimized at the DFT level of theory and analyzed according to the QTAIM method.  shows the Laplacian of the electron density for ligands L1-L4A (the corresponding Laplacian in ligand L4B is shown in the Supporting Information, Figure S1).

elements.content: (a–d) Laplacian of the electron density of the free ligands (L1–L4A) including the net atomic charges of the nitrogens at the imidazole (head) and the oxime (tail). Color coding of the atoms: white = hydrogen, red = oxygen, blue = nitrogen, gray = carbon.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a-d) Laplacian of the electron density of the free ligands (L1-L4A) including the net atomic charges of the nitrogens at the imidazole (head) and the oxime (tail). Color coding of the atoms: white = hydrogen, red = oxygen, blue = nitrogen, gray = carbon.

elements.content: Generally, all four ligands show a larger negative charge at the head than at the tail, which indicates that the head of the ligand would be a preferred coordination site for the positively charged metal center. On the other hand, all ligands exhibit very similar relative difference in the net atomic charges of the coordinating nitrogens. Therefore, electronic reasons alone cannot explain the versatile coordination modes of the imidazole oximes. The major difference in the ligand geometries in the complexes originates from the different torsional behavior of the tail. Therefore, we performed a limited conformational analysis at the DFT level of theory by optimizing three different conformers: the one with the straight oxime tail, the bent one with the OH group pointing to the imidazole nitrogen, and the one with geometry adopted in the complexes, such as in . The optimized geometries and the relative energies are shown in Figure S2. Although in all cases the conformations with the straight oxime tail, which does not have any additional intramolecular interactions, is the least favorable structure, the difference with respect to the bent conformer with strong OH···N­(imidazole) intramolecular interactions is at most 27 kJ mol–1. This is the energy that the ligand needs in order to bind via both coordinative nitrogens. The energy can be easily overcome via additional interactions either with the counteranions (as discussed later), or via other strong intramolecular interactions, like in L2 and L3. It should be noted that in the case of L2 and L3, the energetically most favorable conformer is the one obtained in the complexes. Therefore, we decided to investigate further only the ligand conformers adopted in the complexation with silver.

elements.content: The optimized structure of 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime ligand (L1) showed no additional intramolecular interactions. We selected to optimize the structure of L1 starting from the initial cis conformation of the tail (with the N–C–C–N torsion of 0°), since in this conformation both coordination sites are open for bonding with no steric hindrance from the neighboring groups. According to the charges of the coordinating nitrogens, it can be expected that L1 would most favorably coordinate via the imidazole nitrogen.

According to the charges of the coordinating nitrogens, it can be expected that L1 would most favorably coordinate via the imidazole nitrogen.

elements.content: When the position of the methyl substituent is modified from the imidazole nitrogen to carbon, for instance, in 1H-4­(5)-methylimidazole-5­(4)-carbaldehyde oxime (L4), the most favorable geometry of the ligand is very similar to that of L1, and also similar coordination geometries would be expected. However, as can be seen in b, in solution L4A has another tautomeric form, L4B. The difference in the tautomers will have an impact on the coordination mode.

elements.content: 1H-Imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime (L2), and N-hydroxy-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboximideamide (L3), exhibited additional intramolecular interactions, which had a major effect on the optimized geometries of the free ligands. Especially in L2, the fairly strong O···H­(N) interaction (E INT = −24 kJ mol–1) between the oxime oxygen and the imidazole hydrogen directed the molecule into trans conformation of the coordinating nitrogens. Similarly, hydrogen bonding interaction was found between the amine (−NH2) substituent and the imidazole nitrogen, but with slightly weaker interaction energy of −16 kJ mol–1. Therefore, the active nitrogen sites in both ligands would be too far away to coordinate in a chelating or bridging modes. In addition, the bulky substituents in both the imidazole ring and the oxime tail create steric hindrance at both coordination sites in L3, further complicating the bonding system.

elements.content: The reaction of 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime ligand (L1) with either AgNO3 or AgClO3 yielded similar mononuclear [Ag­(L1)2]+ motif with NO3 – and ClO3 – as counterions, for compounds 1 and 2, respectively (). L1 was found to be distinct in forming a mononuclear chelating silver complex irrespective of the counterions or other reaction conditions. Two ligands are coordinated to the metal through imidazole nitrogen, with Ag(1)–N(1) 2.110(2) and Ag(1)–N(4) 2.112(2) Å for 1 and slightly longer 2.117(2) and 2.129(2) Å for 2. The imidazole groups are in trans position to each other; thus a head-to-head coordination is present with almost linear bond angle N(1)–Ag(1)–N(4) 176.31(6)° for 1 and 173.99(8) for 2. The tails of the ligands interact with the metal center with Ag(1)···N­(3) 2.949(2) and Ag(1)···N(6) 2.9779(14) Å for 1 and 2.937(2) and 2.814(2) Å for 2.

Chelating Coordination Mode

The reaction of 1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime ligand (L1) with either AgNO3 or AgClO3 yielded similar mononuclear [Ag(L1)2]+ motif with NO3 - and ClO3 - as counterions, for compounds 1 and 2, respectively (). L1 was found to be distinct in forming a mononuclear chelating silver complex irrespective of the counterions or other reaction conditions. Two ligands are coordinated to the metal through imidazole nitrogen, with Ag(1)-N(1) 2.110(2) and Ag(1)-N(4) 2.112(2) Å for 1 and slightly longer 2.117(2) and 2.129(2) Å for 2. The imidazole groups are in trans position to each other; thus a head-to-head coordination is present with almost linear bond angle N(1)-Ag(1)-N(4) 176.31(6)° for 1 and 173.99(8) for 2. The tails of the ligands interact with the metal center with Ag(1)⋅⋅⋅N(3) 2.949(2) and Ag(1)⋅⋅⋅N(6) 2.9779(14) Å for 1 and 2.937(2) and 2.814(2) Å for 2.

elements.content: According to the QTAIM calculations, the interaction energies showed stronger interactions of −172 kJ mol–1 from the ligand’s head and weaker from the tail with −15 kJ mol–1 giving rise to the asymmetric chelating coordination. The preferred coordination site at the head of the ligand is in line with the calculated larger negative charge of the imidazole nitrogen compared to that of the oxime nitrogen in the free ligand L1 (a). The asymmetric nature of the chelating coordination was further verified via inspecting the nature of the Ag–N interactions. The selected properties of the electron density can be seen in . The absolute ratio of the potential energy density and kinetic energy density, 1≤ |V|/G ≤ 2, points out that silver coordination to the imidazole group of the ligand exhibits some electron sharing and therefore has partial covalent nature, which is typical for metal–ligand bonding in transition metal complexes. On the other hand, the interaction of the oxime nitrogen with silver has clearly a closed shell noncovalent nature. The calculated local electron density, ρ­(BCP), and the delocalization index, δ­(Ag, N), both suggest electron sharing and thus larger covalent contribution for the interaction of the head than that of the tail.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction measurements showed the formation of a dinuclear complex [Ag­(L4A)]2­[NO3]2 (3), when 1H-5-methylimidazole-4-carbaldehyde oxime (L4A) reacted with AgNO3 (). The Ag atoms are almost linearly (169.3(2)°) coordinated by two ligands, in a head-to-tail arrangement. The dimer has an intramolecular argentophilic interaction of Ag(1)–Ag(1) 2.7592(7) Å. The obtained bond distance is short for the Ag···Ag interaction compared to those reported in the literature with values ranging from 2.6–3.6 Å. Hence the Ag···Ag contacts in complex 3 indicated strong argentophilic interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Dimeric Bridging Coordination Mode

The X-ray diffraction measurements showed the formation of a dinuclear complex [Ag(L4A)]2[NO3]2 (3), when 1H-5-methylimidazole-4-carbaldehyde oxime (L4A) reacted with AgNO3 (). The Ag atoms are almost linearly (169.3(2)°) coordinated by two ligands, in a head-to-tail arrangement. The dimer has an intramolecular argentophilic interaction of Ag(1)-Ag(1) 2.7592(7) Å. The obtained bond distance is short for the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction compared to those reported in the literature with values ranging from 2.6-3.6 Å. Hence the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts in complex 3 indicated strong argentophilic interaction.

elements.content: (a) Crystal structure of the cationic part in dimeric [Ag­(L4A)]2­[NO3]2 (3) and the results from QTAIM analysis. (b) The formation of polymeric chain in the ac-plane by NO3 – counterions.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Crystal structure of the cationic part in dimeric [Ag(L4A)]2[NO3]2 (3) and the results from QTAIM analysis. (b) The formation of polymeric chain in the ac-plane by NO3 - counterions.

elements.content: As already discussed in the case of the free ligands, the coordinating nitrogens in L4A are open for a chelating or bridging coordination. Interestingly, unlike with ligand L1, with L4A the bridging coordination was in this case found to be experimentally more favorable. Moreover, unlike in the asymmetric L1 chelate, both the head and the tail in L4A coordinated symmetrically with similar bond distances. Since the ligands remained effectively planar, the symmetric distances resulted from a twisted coordination with a 33° torsion twist for N(1)–Ag(1)–Ag(1)–N(3) torsional angle (for details, see Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). X-ray diffraction analysis showed that the coordination sphere of silver is further extended by intermolecular oxygen–silver contacts between the metal atom and the nitrate counterions. Between two dimer molecules there are two counterions, which link the neighboring molecules together in a 1D chain in the ac-plane (b). Computational analysis of the axial interactions gave interaction energies of −27.8 kJ mol–1 and −44.0 kJ mol–1 for the two counterions with different Ag–O distances, showing that the counterions have a major impact on the final crystal packing of the molecular compounds in the case of L4A. As a result, both the head and the tail coordinate with similar strong interactions, with interaction energies −144 and −143 kJ mol–1, respectively. Also the nature of both interactions is the same, as can be seen from the properties of the electron density presented in , both the head and the tail coordinate with strong covalent metal–ligand interactions. Even though the interaction strength is smaller than that of the imidazole nitrogen in L1, the substantially stronger interaction from the tail stabilizes the dimeric coordination.

elements.content: The short distance between the two Ag atoms indicated strong argentophilic interaction. The short distance is forced by the relatively short bite distance between the nitrogens at the head and the tail of the ligand L4A. The analysis of the charge density further supports the finding; a strong interaction (E INT = −47 kJ mol–1) with notable covalent contribution is found at the Ag···Ag bond critical point. The argentophilic interaction stabilizes the dimeric structure, where axial sites are left for further coordination, for example, with the counteranions. Therefore, it can be concluded that the interplay between the stronger covalent bonding and fairly strong argentophilic interaction determines the formation of the bridging dimer in 3.

elements.content: A polymeric structure [Ag­(L2)] n ­[NO3] n (4) was formed when 1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime (L2) was reacted with AgNO3 (). In 4, the Ag atom is coordinated by the imidazole nitrogen, Ag(1)–N(1) 2.158(3) Å, and by the oxime nitrogen of the adjacent ligand, Ag(1)–N(3) 2.174(3) Å, to form a zigzag chain with an alternating head-to-tail-to-head arrangement.
elements.clean_text:
Polymeric Bridging Coordination Mode

A polymeric structure [Ag(L2)] n [NO3] n  (4) was formed when 1H-imidazole-2-carbaldehyde oxime (L2) was reacted with AgNO3 (). In 4, the Ag atom is coordinated by the imidazole nitrogen, Ag(1)-N(1) 2.158(3) Å, and by the oxime nitrogen of the adjacent ligand, Ag(1)-N(3) 2.174(3) Å, to form a zigzag chain with an alternating head-to-tail-to-head arrangement.

elements.content: Experimental structure of the polymeric complex 4 cationic part with the results from the QTAIM analysis at a bond critical point (BCP).
elements.clean_text: 4  Experimental structure of the polymeric complex 4 cationic part with the results from the QTAIM analysis at a bond critical point (BCP).

elements.content: The optimized structure of the free ligand L2 showed an additional and fairly strong hydrogen bonding interaction between the OH group of the oxime and the imidazole N–H group, which led to a more favorable trans conformation of the two coordinating nitrogens (b). In the ligand L2, the coordination sites are therefore too far apart to form a chelating or bridging complex with silver ions. However, both sites are free for a terminal coordination of a single metal ion, since they are not sterically blocked with bulky substituents. When both the head and the tail coordinate to silver, it yields a chain-like arrangement of the complexes, which is exactly what is observed in the polymeric complex 4.

elements.content: Similarly with the bridging coordination in 3, also in 4 the head and the tail coordinate with almost the same strength, as can be seen from the interaction energies presented in . Furthermore, the other properties of the electron density are effectively the same, except that in 4 there are no argentophilic interactions between the metal ions. On the other hand, the coordination of the ligand is planar unlike in 3, where the ligand was forced to twist in order to create a suitable Ag···Ag distance for an argentophilic interaction.

elements.content: In the imidazole oxime compounds which are not substituted at nitrogen, such as in 1H-4­(5)-methylimidazole-5­(4)-carbaldehyde oxime (L4), tautomerism is an important feature and can determine the final structure. Experimentally, the effect of tautomerism of ligand L4 can be seen in 1H NMR. For example, the spectrum observed for the reaction solution AgClO3 + L4­(A + B) showed the presence of another product, which can be attributed to a dimeric complex from tautomer L4A. The choice of solvent and silver salt may favor the reaction of one tautomer versus the other and thus have impact on the product, which crystallizes from the solution. The effect of these reaction conditions cannot be fully excluded, though the structure of the free ligand has the crucial role.

elements.content: When L4A, which yielded the dimeric structure 3, is changed to L4B, a polymeric chain [Ag­(L4B)] n ­[ClO3] n (5) is formed (). Unlike in 4, where the silver atoms are symmetrically coordinated by one oxime group and one imidazole nitrogen, in 5 the ligand bridges Ag(1) atom, which is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogens (Ag(1)–N(2): 2.118(5) Å), and Ag(2) atom, which is coordinated by two oxime nitrogens (Ag(2)–N(3): 2.188(5) Å), resulting in alternating head-to-head and tail-to-tail coordinations. The crystal structure is completed when the ClO3 – anions bridge the adjacent chains.

Unlike in 4, where the silver atoms are symmetrically coordinated by one oxime group and one imidazole nitrogen, in 5 the ligand bridges Ag(1) atom, which is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogens (Ag(1)-N(2): 2.118(5) Å), and Ag(2) atom, which is coordinated by two oxime nitrogens (Ag(2)-N(3): 2.188(5) Å), resulting in alternating head-to-head and tail-to-tail coordinations. The crystal structure is completed when the ClO3 - anions bridge the adjacent chains.

elements.content: Polymeric arrangement of experimental [Ag­(L4B)] n ­[ClO3] n (5) with the numbering and the results of the charge density analysis.
elements.clean_text: 5  Polymeric arrangement of experimental [Ag(L4B)] n [ClO3] n  (5) with the numbering and the results of the charge density analysis.

elements.content: Tautomer L4B does not form a dimeric structure like its pair L4A, since in L4B the coordinating imidazole nitrogen of the head is located on the other side of the ligand, and far away from the oxime nitrogen, the tail. Therefore, the only possibility for coordination is a terminal mode, but since again there are no large blocking substituents, both ends are capable of attaching to silver ions. In the structure of 5, the head site is slightly preferred with interaction energies of −165 and −133 kJ mol–1 for the head and the tail, respectively. This can be rationalized with the different electron donating ability of the head and the tail in L4B. The methyl substituent in the imidazole ring near the coordinating nitrogen pushes electron density, which can be seen in a slightly larger value of electron density at the Ag(1)–N(2) bond critical point (), compared to all other ligands. Hence, strong interactions resembling the head-to-head configuration in 1 result from the coordination of the imidazole ring in L4B.

elements.content: A special case with combination of terminal and bridging modes is present in complex [Ag2(L3)4]­[CF3SO3]2THF (6) (), which was formed in the reaction between N-hydroxy-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboximideamide (L3) and AgCF3SO3. In 6, two silver atoms are bridged together by two ligands in head-to-tail configuration as in 3 with Ag(1)–N(5) 2.240(2) and Ag(1)–N(7) 2.3604(13) Å. The Ag(1)–Ag(1) distance of 2.9937(4) Å indicates a formation of a weaker interaction than in 3, but still moderately strong intramolecular argentophilic interaction. Each silver is further terminally coordinated by one ligand via the imidazole nitrogens Ag(1)–N(1) 2.2357(12) Å with a bond angle N(1)–Ag(1)–N(7) 117.221(4)°. The combination of terminal and bridging modes was induced by excess of the ligand in the synthesis of complex 6. It was formed in a ratio of 2:1 for L3:silver in a very coordinative solvent, THF. The synthesis of the other complexes utilized a ligand to Ag ratio of 1:1. When L3 was reacted with silver ions in a 1:1 ratio, a different kind of product compared to 6 was formed with L3, where Ag ratio was 1:1 according to E.A. However, for this compound no suitable crystals for X-ray analysis were formed.

elements.content: The optimized structure of the free ligand L3 showed very sterically blocked coordination sites both for the head and the tail (c). Also, free rotation of the torsion of the tail would be hindered by the bulky NH2 and CH3 substituents, which can also form additional weak intramolecular interactions to stabilize the structure. However, rotation around the N(5)–C(8)–C(9)–N(7) bond would be required for more effective coordination to metal ions since it would lead to a cis conformation of the coordination sites, just like in L1 and L4A. In the case of L4A, it was observed that by forming a twisted coordination the ligand was able to bind in a bridging mode, where additional argentophilic interactions further stabilized the dimeric structure of 3. With L3, larger twisting of the ligand is needed in order to stabilize a dimeric coordination mode (twist angles of 63° and 33° were found for the N(1)–Ag(1)–Ag(1)–N(3) coordination of L3 and L4A, respectively. See Figure S1 for details). Unlike in 3, the coordination of the head and the tail is rather asymmetric with a large preference for the head (E INT = −116 and −79 kJ mol–1 for the head and the tail, respectively), which can be seen as a result of the steric hindrance from the bulky substituents in L3 preventing sufficient adjusting of the ligand structure for coordination. Because of the smaller interaction energies than in the corresponding dimeric structure of 3, it can therefore be suggested that the stability of the compound 6 is much smaller than with the other silver imidazole oxime complexes.

elements.content: In the dimeric coordination mode, the silver ions interact with argentophilic interactions, which in the case of 6 are less pronounced than in 3. However, even though the interaction energy is smaller, −24 kJ mol–1 versus −47 kJ mol–1 in 6 and 3, respectively, the additional attractive interaction is able to stabilize the structure, and the crystalline structure is able to be formed in suitable conditions.

elements.content: Because of the large excess of the ligand, terminally coordinated L3 ligands fill additional coordination sites. As expected from the net atomic charges of free L3, the preferred coordination site is at the head of the ligand. It should be noted that the conformation of the terminally coordinated L3 is much less twisted than the bridging ligand and therefore more similar than the structure optimized for the free ligand, where additional intramolecular interactions make the conformer very stable. On the other hand, the twisted conformer suitable for bridging coordination is only about 29 kJ mol–1 less stable, and it can be easily stabilized via formation of argentophilic interactions. The coordination sphere in 6 is completed by the CF3SO3 – counteranions.

elements.content: In order to investigate the role of the different counteranions in the formation of the structures of the complexes, we created larger models from the corresponding crystal structures including the nearest counteranions (shown in the Supporting Information). The models were analyzed via QTAIM methods, and the interactions between the counteranions and the cationic complexes were compared with other intra- and intermolecular interactions. The results of the analysis are shown in Figures S5–S9.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Counteranions

In order to investigate the role of the different counteranions in the formation of the structures of the complexes, we created larger models from the corresponding crystal structures including the nearest counteranions (shown in the Supporting Information). The models were analyzed via QTAIM methods, and the interactions between the counteranions and the cationic complexes were compared with other intra- and intermolecular interactions. The results of the analysis are shown in Figures S5-S9.

elements.content: In the synthesis of the chelating complexes 1 and 2, the only difference was in the selection of the silver salt, AgNO3 in 1 and AgClO3 in 2. Consequently, very similar structures were formed, and the counterions connected to the cations via rather strong noncovalent O···HO interactions with the noncoordinating OH group of the oxime tail and also via hydrogen bonding from the imidazole hydrogen (Figures S5 and S6). The torsional behavior of the oxime OH was found rather free, and since it does not coordinate to silver, the counterions had no major effect on the formation of the chelating coordination mode. However, the strong interactions with the counteranion can be suggested to assist the free ligand L1 in formation of a favorable conformation for the chelating binding, since the required conformer with a straight oxime tail was found about 27 kJ mol–1 less stable than the bent conformer with intramolecular N···HO interactions (for details, see Supporting Information, Figure S2).

elements.content: In the bridging dimeric coordination mode in complex 3, the NO3 – counterions occupied the axial sites of the dimers, and hence connected adjacent molecules into chains, as can be seen in . Again, the interaction between the counterion and the cationic complex was rather strong (Figure S7), but since the counterions occupied otherwise free sites, it can be concluded that the formation of the dimeric coordination determined the chain-like structure and the role of the counterions was to direct the packing of the chains.

Again, the interaction between the counterion and the cationic complex was rather strong (Figure S7), but since the counterions occupied otherwise free sites, it can be concluded that the formation of the dimeric coordination determined the chain-like structure and the role of the counterions was to direct the packing of the chains.

elements.content: The polymeric chains were formed in complexes 4 and 5 via reaction of silver salts and ligands L2 and L4B, respectively. Both free ligands adopt a bent conformer by using intramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions, and this most favorable conformer is maintained in the complexes (Figure S2). Because of the bent ligand tail, the coordinating nitrogens are located too far to be chelating or bridging. However, the strong interactions of the counterions with OH groups of the oxime tail can be expected assist the torsional behavior of the OH group, therefore somewhat affecting the intramolecular interactions in the ligands (Figures S8 and S9). On the other hand, the interactions are similar regardless of the selection of the counterion, NO3 – or ClO3 –, and therefore, the main role of the counteranions is to connect adjacent chains.

elements.content: In the final structure 6, the triflate counterion again occupied the axial site of the dimeric complex, with strong O···HO interactions with the bridging oxime tail, similarly to compound 3. However, the bulky axial ligands prevented the formation of similar chains of dimers, and consequently, separate molecules were connected only via very weak hydrogen bonding interactions in the crystalline state.

elements.content: Imidazole oximes have very rich coordination chemistry, which is a result of having two potential donor nitrogens with completely different electronic environments in coordinating to metal ions. The imidazole oxime ligands, L1–L4, studied in this work were all electronically very similar, and only small differences could be found in their charge distribution and the properties of the electron density. The computational results on the free ligands suggested clear coordinative preference for the imidazole nitrogen over the oxime nitrogen. The more favored coordination site of the head led to formation of chelating mononuclear silver complexes 1 and 2, with an asymmetric weaker interaction from the nitrogen of the tail.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Imidazole oximes have very rich coordination chemistry, which is a result of having two potential donor nitrogens with completely different electronic environments in coordinating to metal ions. The imidazole oxime ligands, L1-L4, studied in this work were all electronically very similar, and only small differences could be found in their charge distribution and the properties of the electron density. The computational results on the free ligands suggested clear coordinative preference for the imidazole nitrogen over the oxime nitrogen. The more favored coordination site of the head led to formation of chelating mononuclear silver complexes 1 and 2, with an asymmetric weaker interaction from the nitrogen of the tail.

elements.content: However, with subtle modifications in the structure of the ligands by, for example, using different substituents in the neighborhood of the coordinating nitrogens, or by using different tautomeric form of the imidazole ring, we were able to change the preference of the coordination site and form a large variety of silver complexes with different coordination modes, including bridging dimeric and polymeric chain-like forms, and also a structure with a combination of bridging and terminal coordination modes. Computational analysis revealed that the major reason for the versatile coordination of the ligands can be found in the geometry of the free ligands, especially the torsional behavior of the oxime tail, which in turn is affected by weak intramolecular interactions between the different groups. The differences in the coordination strength can also be rationalized via additional stabilizing intramolecular interactions formed in the coordination, including fairly strong argentophilic interactions obtained in the dinuclear complexes 3 and 6 with bridging imidazole oximes. Additionally, the counterions were found to have a role in packing of the solid state structures, for example, by binding adjacent rows or dimers to more extended structures via intermolecular noncovalent interactions. However, they did not have a major effect in determining the actual coordination modes, which was shown by QTAIM analysis of the intermolecular interactions with more extended computational models. It can be suggested that the structural differences will also affect the electronic and optical properties of the materials, and therefore, the silver imidazole oximes can be regarded as an interesting example of structure-related design of novel coordination complexes.

Calc. for AgC4H5N4O4 C % 17.10; H % 1.79; N % 19.94. Found. C % 16.80; H % 1.96; N % 19.38.

Complex 5 

A solution of 1H-4-methylimidazole-5-carbaldehyde oxime (L4) (19.5 mg, 0.156 mmol) in dried methanol (1.0 mL) was combined with a solution of AgClO3 (29.6 mg, 0.154 mmol v.s. 4B in 4 according to NMR) in dried acetonitrile (0.5 mL). Crystallization at 2 °C gave colorless crystals (yield 6.5 mg, 26.2%) 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 2.34 (CH3, 3H); 7.53 (imidazole ring, 1H); 7.89 (HCN, 1H); 11.75 (NOH, 1H); 12.60 (NH, 1H) ppm. Calc. for AgClC5H7N3O4 C % 18.98; H % 2.23; N %13.28. Found. C % 19.84; H % 2.58; N % 12.85. Minor dimeric compound: 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 2.31 (CH3, 3H); 8.03 (imidazole ring, 1H); 8.23 (HCN, 1H); 11.17 (NOH, 1H); 12.87 (NH, 1H) ppm.

Complex 6 

A solution of N-hydroxy-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboximiamide (L3) (16.8 mg, 0.120 mmol) in dried THF (2.0 mL) was combined with a solution of AgCF3SO3 (15.0 mg, 0.061 mmol) in dried THF (0.5 mL). Crystallization at 2 °C gave colorless crystals (yield 3.4 mg, 18.7%). 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ 3.81 (CH3, 3H); 5.99 (NH2, 2H); 7.00 (imidazole ring, 1H); 7.33 (imidazole ring, 1H); 10.03 (OH, 1H) ppm. Calc. for AgC15H24N8O6SF3 C % 29.56; H % 3.97; N % 18.39; S % 5.26. Found. C % 29.04; H % 3.90; N % 18.36; S % 5.57.
